headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: SpaceX's Starship Rocket Launch Set For 9 AM ET; CNN Crew Travels With Migrants Making Treacherous Journey To U.S.; Report: Rise In Antisemitic Incidents In U.S. And Other Countries In 2022. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL SMERCONISH, CNN HOST, SMERCONISH
utterances.sentences: He doesn't say anything about it --

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMERCONISH
utterances.sentences: -- because I believe Trump recognizes that the issue is a net loser in a general election.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But --

utterances.speaker: SMERCONISH
utterances.sentences: General election.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- remember when he was running he told Lesley Stahl on "60 MINUTES" I will work and appoint pro-life judges.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But you're right, DeSantis signed that bill at like 11

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No cameras on him. No trying to get that in the headlines.Michael, thanks very much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Michael. I'll be listening to you today and watching you on the weekends.

utterances.speaker: SMERCONISH
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right, see you -- bye-bye.

utterances.speaker: SMERCONISH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So this morning, SpaceX expected to test its most powerful rocket yet. So why is CEO Elon Musk -- Elon Musk telling people not to get too excited?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I love this song.(COMMERCIAL)

utterances.speaker: ED LAVANDERA, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, it's exciting because we don't really know what's going to happen here over the next few hours. But there are thousands of people here on the southern edge of South Padre Island. We are about five miles away from that launch pad.The window for SpaceX to launch this rocket opens about 7:00 a.m. central time. They have about three hours to get that done. SpaceX is saying that they are looking around 8:00 a.m. central time for a launch here. But the way Elon Musk is talking about this, this could be a spectacular success or an epic fireworks show. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) LAVANDERA (voice-over):  The SpaceX Starship is the most powerful rocket ever built. It's 400 feet tall. The super-heavy booster is packed with 33 engines, and it will attempt to push the uncrewed Starship spacecraft, which sits on top of the rocket booster, into space. If the rocket launches properly the spacecraft will separate less than three minutes into the flight and travel east from south Texas and go much of the way around the Earth before splashing into the Pacific Ocean near Hawaii. But hours before this scheduled launch, SpaceX founder Elon Musk worked to lower expectations to the point that he seemed to be bracing for catastrophic failure.

utterances.speaker: ELON MUSK, FOUNDER AND CEO, SPACEX
utterances.sentences: Success is not what should be expected. That would be insane. This vehicle could make it all the way to orbit or it may blow up on the pad. There's a million ways this rocket could fail.LAVANDERA (voice-over):  SpaceX has waited more than a year for the final government clearance to launch this rocket. The Starship rocket system is the centerpiece of Musk's goal of commercial space travel to the moon and beyond to Mars. It comes two weeks after NASA unveiled the four astronauts who will fly around the moon next year as part of the space agency's Artemis mission. NASA has awarded SpaceX contracts and options of more than $3 billion to use Starship to ferry future Artemis astronauts to the moon. NASA Artemis II commander Reid Wiseman spoke with CNN about the importance of this partnership for humans to eventually reach Mars.

utterances.speaker: REID WISEMAN, COMMANDER, ARTEMIS II
utterances.sentences: I think we will get there. The amount of private-public partnerships going on -- SpaceX is building our lander for the moon. They're working on Starship right now. We have -- commercial space is just doing amazing things right now. So to think that humans will be walking on Mars in 20 years is completely reasonable.LAVANDERA (voice-over):  Testing on this rocket system started several years ago and it's resulted in many breakthroughs --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Two, one, ignition, abort.LAVANDERA (voice-over):  -- but also some explosive setbacks. Thousands of people are expected to crowd the beaches miles from the launchpad to catch a glimpse of this rocket launch. In the crowd will be Yemi Akinyemi Dele. The Czech Nigerian artist has already been selected as one of the first eight passengers who will eventually fly in the Starship capsule on its first commercial flight around the moon. LAVANDERA (on camera):  Are you looking at it as one day I'm going to be sitting in that rocket and I want to know what it's going to be like?

utterances.speaker: YEMI AKINYEMI DELE, FUTURE SPACEX MISSION CREW MEMBER
utterances.sentences: Well, for the first time, I'm going to see how it looks from close up and I will be able to imagine how it would feel. But just imagine how it would feel to sit in it and be leaving the Earth.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: So, Don, here is a breakdown. A best-case scenario -- the timeline of how this will work is after the rocket launches the booster will separate from the rocket ship on top, and that will land in the Gulf of Mexico. Then the Starship will continue to make almost one complete orbit around the Earth, as we mentioned, landing in the Pacific Ocean. Both of those pieces will land in the water and company officials tell us that there are no plans to recover them, so they will sink to the bottom of the waters, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow, and who's got the best seat in the house? Ed Lavandera.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Eddie --

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: Not too bad. Not too bad.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Eddie, do you know Yemi is one of my best friends? Did he tell you?

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: I heard -- I heard some -- I heard something about that yesterday.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Scuttlebutt.

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: He was unbelievably delightful --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He --

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: -- and an absolutely fascinating guy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He's an amazing human and I am not -- he has had this goal to go to the moon for years. He told us about five years ago he was going to go to the moon and I said, "Yes, Yemi. If someone is going to -- a civilian -- it's going to be you." So it's amazing to see how far he's come, Ed.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Awesome.

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: Well, his story is fascinating.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: He said he grew up with barely any electricity in his house as a young child in Czechoslovakia --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: -- and now he is, you know, several years away from traveling to the moon.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: Yes, awesome.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He's a great guy. Ed, thanks.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Ed.

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: Yes, he's great.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So I'd love to meet him. And you say you wouldn't go. I would go. I would go.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I would never go. I know you would.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You're fearless.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Would you guys go? Would you go? No?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: To the moon? Everyone in the crew is shaking their head no.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good to hear.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow, look at that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, look at that.And this morning we're live in El Paso, Texas where officials are bracing for another surge of migrants. Plus, we're taking a look at their dangerous journey to the border. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) UNIDENTIFIED MALE (translated):  You're waiting for your parents? Where are they? CHILD (translated):  They are behind. (END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: On the rocks. It's hard. My mom fell down so many times.UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (translated):  -- or let my son come through here. This is horrible, horrible, horrible. You have to live this. You have to live this. You have to live this to realize that crossing through this jungle is the worst thing in the world. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, the migrants who do compete -- or complete, excuse me, the treacherous journey to the U.S. border meet more obstacles when they arrive.I want to get to CNN's Rosa Flores. She is live in El Paso, Texas on the border with more on the trek and what happens once migrants make it through. Rosa, good morning. We spoke with you. You were in front of the same shelter just one year ago. What are you seeing now?

utterances.speaker: ROSA FLORES, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Don. The last time we were here was actually in January and there were hundreds of migrants sleeping on the street. Let me show you what we can see now. There's several dozen, actually, sleeping on the street. This is just outside Sacred Heart Church, which is a migrant shelter.I talked to the priest that runs the shelter late yesterday and this is what he feared, he told me. He said that his shelter was already full and that he feared that some people were going to have to sleep on the street, and that's exactly what we're seeing this morning. And he said that he hasn't seen this since January. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) FLORES (on camera):  Where are we?

utterances.speaker: FATHER JAVIER CALVILLO, DIRECTOR, CASA DEL MIGRANTE
utterances.sentences: (Speaking foreign language).FLORES (voice-over):  Father Javier Calvillo runs the Casa Del Migrante shelter in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico across the border from El Paso, Texas, and says this is one of about 40 shelters in the city --

utterances.speaker: CALVILLO
utterances.sentences: (Speaking foreign language).FLORES (voice-over):  -- and that most of the migrants here are from Venezuela. FLORES (on camera):  The top nationality is Venezuelan?

utterances.speaker: CALVILLO
utterances.sentences: Yes.FLORES (voice-over):  And the majority, if not all, are part of the skyrocketing number of migrants trekking through the dangerous jungle passage between Colombia and Panama known as the Darien Gap. Migrant crossings there have jumped from under 600 in 2010 to nearly a quarter-million last year. This year, nearly 90,000 migrants have made the trek so far, all of them on their way to the U.S. southern border. The Biden administration took notice and alongside Colombia and Panama, it launched a two-month campaign to curb the flow of migration.

utterances.speaker: CALVILLO
utterances.sentences: El juego de la politica. FLORES (on camera)

utterances.speaker: CALVILLO
utterances.sentences: Yes.FLORES (voice-over):  Both the U.S. and Mexico, for what he calls the game of politics and policies. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Now, I'm in the alley in the back of that church and take a look. There's more people who are sleeping out here -- that there is no space for them inside the shelter.Now, the Department of Homeland Security has said that the Biden administration has launched a comprehensive immigration strategy that is fair and efficient and that it allows for legal pathways to enter into the United States, and that includes the CBP One app, which you saw in that story just now. Now, U.S. Customs and Border Protection says that the CBP One app is working as intended and that tens of thousands of migrants have already used it to set up appointments to enter into the United States. But, Poppy and Don, you can see that there are still migrants here outside. And again, we haven't seen this since January. And Poppy, you probably remember this very clearly because we were on the air at the same time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: There were hundreds of people. Now, yes, there's fewer people but is this the spike before the end of Title 42? We don't know. We'll see.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's the big question.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Back to you guys.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Tonight marks the start of Holocaust Remembrance Day. Across the world, victims of the Holocaust will be remembered and the survivors will be honored. This morning, new sobering data is revealing a significant increase inantisemitic incidents worldwide. In the U.S. specifically, the Antidefamation League recorded nearly 3,700 antisemitic incidents in 2022 compared to more than 2,700 in 2021 -- a record year in its own right. So joining us now, Jonathan Greenblatt, the CEO and the national director of the Antidefamation League. We're so happy to have you on to discuss this. We wish it was good news. Unfortunately, it's not. What is behind this?

utterances.speaker: JONATHAN GREENBLATT, CEO AND NATIONAL DIRECTOR, ANTIDEFAMATION LEAGUE
utterances.sentences: Well, Don, I think you could imagine antisemitism is the canary in the coal mine of democracy. And this new data, which we're releasing today in partnership with Tel Aviv University, shows a frightening and unfortunately, almost predictable increase in antisemitism worldwide.So we saw across Europe in places like Belgium, Hungary, Italy, Switzerland, Spain -- places like Australia -- all around the world you're seeing this rise of attacks, vandalism, violence perpetrated against Jewish people.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: There are some places that I want to talk about where it's actually decreasing --

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- but let's -- I wonder what kind of attacks are happening now and who are the victims?

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Well, it's interesting you ask. I mean, one of the trends is certainly Orthodox Jews --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: -- Haredi Jews, who are visibly Jewish, wearing a kippah, maybe a black hat, maybe wearing a wig. As we see here in New York, particularly in Brooklyn, the Stamford Hill neighborhood in London, they bear the brunt of physical abrasive antisemitism.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You talked about what happened here. It examines these assaults in New York City. The city recorded the most assaults in the U.S.

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We've talked about some of those incidents.Why does this continue do you think, Jonathan? What do you think what really needs to change here?

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Well, I think there are a few things that are driving this and there is some very interesting data in this report --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. GREENBLATTSo it's a go-to tactic of the bad guys. The invisible Jews are being targeted. And I think why is it happening? You see this polarization in all of these democratic societies. You see extremists feeling emboldened around the world. And then social media continues to exacerbate and intensify the problem.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: On the other hand, you talked about the countries where it's increasing --

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- countries including Germany, Austria, France --

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- the U.K., Canada, Argentina. They saw a decline in the number of antisemitic incidents --

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- compared to 2021.

utterances.speaker: GREENBLATT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Are leaders there doing the right thing? Are they doing something differently than the leaders in places --
